      • getBatchSubmitMax

        public int getBatchSubmitMax()
        Gets the maximum number of destinations that can be submitted in a single batch.

        If you intend to receive the submission status for each destination immediately after submitting the message, you must check the total number of destinations added against this value. If the total number of destinations added is equal to the value returned from this method, you must submit to those recipients, clear the recipients list, and then continue the cycle.

        However, if the total number of destinations added is greater than the value returned from this method, submission status of the destinations will not be returned but rather a token that you can use to query submission status. In that case, there would not be any need for this value.

        Note that if the number of destinations added is equal to the maximum submission value, any attempt to add another destination will throw an Exception.

        Returns:
        Returns the maximum number of destinations that can be submitted in a single batch.

        public MSGTYPE getMessageType()

        Returns:
        Returns the type of message that will be sent.
        See Also:
        setMessageType(Zenoph.SMSLib.Enums.MSGTYPE), setMessageType(java.lang.String)
        Note:
        The default message type for user account is loaded and set as the default when using this API. To change the type of message to be sent, a call to setMessageType(Zenoph.SMSLib.Enums.MSGTYPE) or setMessageType(java.lang.String) must be made.

      • schedule

        public void schedule(java.util.Date datetime)
        Sets a date and time at which the message should be submitted to the destinations.
        Parameters:
        datetime - The local date and time at which the message should be submitted to the destinations.
        See Also:
        schedule(java.util.Date, java.lang.String), schedule(java.util.Date, java.lang.String, java.lang.String)
        Note:

        The method determines the GMT offset from the default time zone as set in user accounts. When setting datetime for a different time zone other than the one set in user account, the overloaded methods can be used to specify the time zone offset to be used for datetime.

        When the date and time has been set and scheduling needs to be cancelled, a call to the method with a null argument will cancel the scheduling.

        The time portion of datetime must be in 24 hour format.

      • schedule

        public void schedule(java.util.Date datetime,
                     java.lang.String gmtoffset)
              throws java.lang.Exception
        Sets a date and time at which the message should be submitted to the destinations.
        Parameters:
        datetime - The local date and time at which the message should be submitted to the destinations.
        gmtoffset - The time offset from GMT for the destinations.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown if datetime is null or when gmtoffset is invalid.
        See Also:
        schedule(java.util.Date), schedule(java.util.Date, java.lang.String, java.lang.String)
        Note:
        datetime should be a local date and time specified in 24hr format. gmtoffset is the time offset from GMT for the destinations. When setting the date and time from a country with daylight saving time, gmtoffset must be explicitly set to the correct GMT offset that is currently being used.

        To cancel message scheduling, the overloaded method schedule(java.util.Date) needs to be called with datetime set to null.

      • schedule

        public void schedule(java.util.Date datetime,
                     java.lang.String tzregion,
                     java.lang.String tzcity)
              throws java.lang.Exception
        Sets a date and time at which the message should be submitted to the destinations.
        Parameters:
        datetime - The local date and time at which the message should be submitted to the destinations.
        tzregion - The time zone region of the destinations (eg. Africa, Europe, America, etc.)
        tzcity - A city from which a time zone offset from GMT should be determined (eg. Accra).
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown if datetime is null or when tzregion and tzcity pair do not identify a valid PHP time zone.
        Note:
        The method determines the GMT offset to be used as the time zone based on tzregion (the time zone region) and tzcity (a relative time zone city). tzregion should be one of the regions such as Africa, Europe, Asia, etc., whiles tzcity should be one of the cities which uses the same time as meant for the specified date and time.

        tzregion and tzcity are not arbitrary but should be one of the time zone region and city pairs available at the API section of the website. These are actually provided by PHP. The cities are not necessarily where a user or recipient is located but rather a reference to a city that uses the same time as meant for the specified date and time.

        With this method, there is no need to worry about daylight saving time changes. Once the correct region and reference city are set, the time offset from GMT is automatically determined and is used for datetime.

      • addRecipient

        public boolean addRecipient(java.lang.String phonenum)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Adds a phone number to the destinations list. If the phone number already exists, it will be ignored.
        Parameters:
        phonenum - The phone number to be added to the destinations list.
        Returns:
        Returns true if the phone number is successfully added otherwise it returns false.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown if phonenum is invalid or not allowed on user routes.
        See Also:
        addRecipient(java.lang.String, boolean), addRecipient(java.lang.String, java.lang.String[]), addRecipient(java.lang.String, java.lang.String[], boolean)
        Note:
        The phone number can be in local or international format. When phonenum is specified in local number format, the default international dial code for user account will be prepended to the phone number to make it international. For example, the phone number can be set as 0246314915, 246314915, 233246314915, or +233246314915

        If phonenum is invalid or not allowed on user routes, Exception will be thrown. To ignore the throwing of Exception when phonenum is invalid or not allowed on user routes, call addRecipient(java.lang.String, boolean) and pass true as the second argument to the method call.

      • addRecipient

        public boolean addRecipient(java.lang.String phonenum,
                            boolean throwex)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Adds a phone number to the destinations list. If the phone number already exists, it will be ignored.
        Parameters:
        phonenum - The phone number to be added to the destinations list.
        throwex - An indicator that specifies whether or not Exception should be thrown when phonenum is invalid or not allowed on user routes.
        Returns:
        Returns true if the phone number is added to the destinations list, otherwise it returns false.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown if any of the following conditions is true:
        • phonenum is not a valid phone number and throwex is set to true.
        • phonenum is not allowed on user routes and throwex is set to true.
        • The set message contains variables for personalised messaging. This is irrespective of the value set for throwex.
        See Also:
        addRecipient(java.lang.String), addRecipient(java.lang.String, java.lang.String[]), addRecipient(java.lang.String, java.lang.String[], boolean)
        Note:
        The essence of throwex is particularly to prevent the termination of a loop that adds destinations. This can be achieved by setting throwex to false from calls in an iteration. In this case, the method will not terminate the iteration but will reject the invalid phone number and get the next.

        If it is a requirement that all phone numbers be added before submission is done, throwex can be set to true. Then when a phone number is rejected, the iteration will be terminated and an Exception thrown to notify the rejection. Setting throwex to true is the same as making a call to the overloaded method addRecipient(java.lang.String).

      • addRecipient

        public boolean addRecipient(java.lang.String phonenum,
                            java.lang.String[] vals)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Adds a phone number and its personalised values to the destinations list. If the phone number already exists, the personalised values will replace the existing one.
        Parameters:
        phonenum - The phone number to be added to the destinations list.
        vals - The personalised values for the destination.
        Returns:
        Returns true if the phone number and personalised values are successfully added, otherwise it returns false.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown if the phone number is is invalid, not allowed on user routes, or when the personalised values are invalid.
        See Also:
        addRecipient(java.lang.String), addRecipient(java.lang.String, boolean), addRecipient(java.lang.String, java.lang.String[], boolean)
        Note:
        The method adds a phone number and its personalised values to the destinations list. When adding personalised values for destination, the message must already be set and contain variables. The total number of values must be equal to the number of variables defined in the set message. Additionally, the values must be ordered to match each variable defined in the message. This method will throw Exception if either the phone number is not added or when the personalised values for the destination are invalid. If the throwing of Exception needs to be ignored, especially in an iteration, the overloaded method addRecipient(java.lang.String, java.lang.String[], boolean) must be called instead passing false as the third argument.

      • addRecipient

        public boolean addRecipient(java.lang.String phonenum,
                            java.lang.String[] values,
                            boolean throwex)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Adds a phone number and its personalised values to the destinations list. If the phone number already exists, the personalised values will replace the existing one.
        Parameters:
        phonenum - The phone number to be added to the destinations list.
        values - The personalised values for the destination.
        throwex - An indicator that specifies whether or not the Exception should be thrown if either the phone number is invalid, not allowed on user routes, or when the personalised values are invalid.
        Returns:
        Returns true if the phone number and its personalised values are successfully added to the destinations list, otherwise it returns false.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown if any of the following conditions is true:
        • phonenum is not a valid phone number and throwex is set to true.
        • phonenum is not allowed on user routes and throwex is set to true.
        • values is invalid and throwex is set to true.
        See Also:
        addRecipient(java.lang.String), addRecipient(java.lang.String, java.lang.String[]), addRecipient(java.lang.String, boolean)
        Note:
        The method adds a phone number and its personalised values to the destinations list. When adding personalised values for destination, the message must already be set and contain variables. The total number of values must be equal to the number of variables defined in the set message. Additionally, the values must be ordered to match each variable defined in the message.

      • addRecipients

        public int addRecipients(java.util.List<java.lang.String> numbers,
                         boolean throwex)
                  throws java.lang.Exception
        Adds a list of phone numbers to the destinations list.
        Parameters:
        numbers - The list of phone numbers to be added to the destinations list.
        throwex - An indicator that tells whether or not the method should ignore the throwing of Exception when a phone number in the list is rejected for its invalidity or when it is not allowed on the user routes.
        Returns:
        Returns the count of phone numbers from the list that were actually added to the destinations list.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown if numbers is null.
        Note:
        The essence of throwex is particularly to prevent the termination of an iteration of adding phone numbers. This can be achieved by setting throwex to false. In this case, the method will not terminate and throw Exception when any of the phone numbers is invalid or not allowed on the routes. It will ignore it and check the next one.

        When there is the need to ensure that all phone numbers are added before submission, throwex must be set to true. Then when a phone number is rejected, the iteration will be terminated and Exception thrown to notify the rejection.

        The method also ensures that each phone number does not already exist before being added. If a phone number already exists, it will be ignored.

      • getRecipients

        public java.lang.String[] getRecipients()
        Gets the list of phone numbers added to the destinations list.
        Returns:
        Returns the list of phone numbers added to the destinations list.

      • isValidPhoneNumber

        public boolean isValidPhoneNumber(java.lang.String phonenum,
                                  boolean onroutes)
        Checks whether the specified value is a valid phone number or not.
        Parameters:
        phonenum - The value to check whether it is a valid phone number or not
        onroutes - Indicates whether the phone number should also be checked against user routes or not.
        Returns:
        When onroutes is set to false, the method returns true if phonenum is a valid phone number. When onroutes is set to true, the method returns true if phonenum is a valid phone number and also allowed on the user's routes. otherwise it returns false.
        See Also:
        isValidPhoneNumber(java.lang.String)

      • isValidPhoneNumber

        public static boolean isValidPhoneNumber(java.lang.String phonenum)
        Checks whether the specified value is a valid phone number or not.
        Parameters:
        phonenum - The value to check whether it is a valid phone number or not.
        Returns:
        Returns true if phonenum is a valid phone number, otherwise it returns false.
        See Also:
        isValidPhoneNumber(java.lang.String)
        Note:
        By default, this method does not check phonenum against user routes. That is, it does not check whether phonenum is allowed on user routes. To check for phone number validity and also to see if it is allowed on user routes, a call to the overloaded method isValidPhoneNumber(java.lang.String, boolean) is required while passing true as the second argument to the method.

      • parsePhoneNumber

        public java.lang.String parsePhoneNumber(java.lang.String phonenum)
                                  throws java.lang.Exception
        Parses a phone number into international format.
        Parameters:
        phonenum - The phone number to be parsed into international format.
        Returns:
        Returns the phone number in international format for submission. If the phone number is invalid or not allowed on user routes, the return value will be null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown if authentication has not been performed for user routes to be loaded or when phonenum is invalid.
        Note:
        The method parses the phone number and returns it in a specific international format. For example, if the phone number is given as 0023320xxxxxxx, the method will parse the phone number and return it in the form 23320xxxxxx. Hence, phone numbers can be specified with the leading +, 00, or without them.

        Phone numbers can also be specified in local format with or without the leading zero (0). For example, 0246xxxxxx, 246xxxxxx. In this case, the method will automatically format the phone numbers in international format by choosing the default international dial code set to be used. If no international dial code has been set for the current session, the default international dial code set for user account will be prepended to phone numbers given in local number format. See the discussion on setDefaultDialCode(java.lang.String) for setting international dial code to be used for phone numbers specified in local format.

        The method also ensures that phone numbers passed to it are valid and that they are allowed on user routes. If a phone number is invalid or not allowed on user routes, the method returns null.

      • getSMSCount

        public int getSMSCount()
                throws java.lang.Exception
        Gets the count of SMS for a single destination based on the length and type of the composed message.
        Returns:
        Returns the count of SMS based on the type and length of the message.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown when not authenticated before making the method call.
        See Also:
        getSMSCount(java.lang.String, Zenoph.SMSLib.Enums.MSGTYPE), getSMSCount(java.lang.String, java.lang.String)
        Note:
        The value returned from the method call depends on the length and type of the message. This return value is the count of the composed SMS and indictates the total credits required for a single destination. If there are multiple destinations to deliver the SMS, the total credits required will be the count of the SMS returned from a call to this method multiplied by the total number of destinations.

        If the message has not been set at the time of the method call, the return value will be zero (0).

      • getSMSCount

        public static int getSMSCount(java.lang.String message,
                              MSGTYPE type)
                       throws java.lang.Exception
        Gets the count of SMS for a single destination based on type and length of the composed message.
        Parameters:
        message - The message for which SMS count should be determined, based on the type of message passed as type.
        type - The type of message for which SMS should be determined, based on the length of message. This must be one of MSGTYPE enumerations.
        Returns:
        Returns the count of SMS based on the type and length of the message.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown when not authenticated before making the method call or when type is invalid.
        See Also:
        getSMSCount(), getSMSCount(java.lang.String, java.lang.String)
        Note:
        The value returned from the method call depends on the length and type of the message. This return value is the count of the composed SMS and indictates the total credits required for a single destination. If there are multiple destinations to deliver the SMS, the total credits required will be the count of the SMS returned from a call to this method multiplied by the total number of destinations.

        If the message has not been set at the time of the method call, the return value will be zero (0).

      • getSMSCount

        public static int getSMSCount(java.lang.String message,
                              java.lang.String type)
                       throws java.lang.Exception
        Gets the count of SMS for a single destination based on type and length of the composed message.
        Parameters:
        message - The message for which SMS count should be determined, based on the type of message passed as type
        type - The type of message for which SMS count should be determined, based on the length of message.
        Returns:
        Returns the count of SMS based on the type and length of the message.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown when not authenticated before making the method call or when type is invalid.
        See Also:
        getSMSCount(), getSMSCount(java.lang.String, Zenoph.SMSLib.Enums.MSGTYPE)
        Note:
        The value returned from the method call depends on the length and type of the message. This return value is the count of the composed SMS and indictates the total credits required for a single destination. If there are multiple destinations to deliver the SMS, the total credits required will be the count of the SMS returned from a call to this method multiplied by the total number of destinations.

        If the message has not been set at the time of the method call, the return value will be zero (0).

      • messageTypeToString

        public static java.lang.String messageTypeToString(MSGTYPE type)
                                            throws java.lang.Exception
        Converts a MSGTYPE enumerator to a String object.
        Parameters:
        type - The MSGTYPE enumerator for which its String representation should be returned.
        Returns:
        Returns a String representation of MSGTYPE enumerator.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown if type is not a MSGTYPE enumerator or when user authentication has not been performed.
        See Also:
        messageTypeToEnum(java.lang.String)
        Note:
        This method can be called if a string representation of any of the MSGTYPE enumeration is needed so that it can be shown, for instance, in GUI forms. A string representation of all the MSGTYPE enumeration can also be obtained by calling the static method getMessageTypes().

        User authentication must be performed for message types to be loaded into memory before calling this method otherwise Exception will be thrown.

      • messageTypeToEnum

        public static MSGTYPE messageTypeToEnum(java.lang.String type)
                                 throws java.lang.Exception
        Converts a String representation of a MSGTYPE enumerator to its corresponding MSGTYPE enumeration type.
        Parameters:
        type - A String object that represents one of the MSGTYPE enumeration. type must be a String object returned from messageTypeToString(Zenoph.SMSLib.Enums.MSGTYPE) or one of the list items returned from getMessageTypes()
        Returns:
        Returns a MSGTYPE enumerator based on type.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown if type does not represent any of the MSGTYPE enumeration.
        See Also:
        messageTypeToString(Zenoph.SMSLib.Enums.MSGTYPE)

      • setDefaultDialCode

        public void setDefaultDialCode(java.lang.String dialcode)
                        throws java.lang.Exception
        Sets the default international dial code to be used for phone numbers not in international format.
        Parameters:
        dialcode - The default international dial code to be set for phone numbers not in international format.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown if the specified dial code is invalid or when it does not exist in user routes.
        Note:
        The default international dial code is used when phone numbers being added to the destinations list are not given in international format but rather in local format. This is prepended to phone numbers specified without international dial codes.

        On successful authentication, the default dial code for a user account is always loaded and set when using the SMS API. When adding phone numbers not given in international format but which uses a different international dial codes, you must first make a call to this method and specify the international dial code to use for subsequent phone numbers without international dial code.

        The international dial code that you set must be one that has already been activated for your account otherwise an Exception will be thrown.

        It must be emphasised that international dial codes set with this method are temporal and do not overwrite the default international dial code set for user account. They are used only for the current session when using the SMS API. On every successful authentication, the default international dial code set for a user account is loaded into memory and used until it is overwritten with a call to this method.

      • getDefaultDialCode

        public java.lang.String getDefaultDialCode()
        Gets the default international dial code that is prepended to phone numbers without international dial code.
        Returns:
        Returns the default international dial code that will be prepended to phone numbers without international dial code.
        See Also:
        setDefaultDialCode(java.lang.String)
        Note:
        This method is handy when there is the need to know the default international dial code that will be preprended to phone numbers not in international format but have been specified to be added to the destinations list. If the default international dial code returned from this method is different from that of subsequent phone numbers to be added but which are not in international format, setDefaultDialCode(java.lang.String) must be called, passing in the international dial code to be used for subsequent phone numbers to be added which are not in international format.

      • getRecipientsCount

        public int getRecipientsCount()
        Gets the total number of phone numbers that have been added to the destinations list.
        Returns:
        Returns the total number of phone numbers added to the destinations list.

      • setSenderId

        public void setSenderId(java.lang.String sdrid)
                 throws java.lang.Exception
        Sets the sender ID of submitted message. This is what appears on the recipient's phone as the sender of the message.
        Parameters:
        sdrid - The ID received on a recipient's phone as the sender of the message.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown if sdrid is null or empty. For alphanumeric sender ID, the Exception will be thrown if the number of characters is greater than 11. For phone numbers, the Exception will be thrown if the number of characters is greater than 18 characters.
        Note:
        When set as phone number, the maximum length should be 18 characters, and when set as alphanumeric sender ID, the maximum length should be 11 characters. If a default sender ID is set for user account, it is automatically loaded and set during authentication.

      • getCreditsBalance

        public int getCreditsBalance()
                      throws SMSException,
                             java.lang.Exception
        Gets the credits balance for user account.
        Returns:
        Returns the credits balance user account.
        Throws:
        SMSException - Thrown if server request fails.
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown when error occurs before request is sent to the server.
        Note:
        The value returned from this method call is the total number of destinations that a message can be submitted to given that the SMS count is 1. For any composed message, the SMS count can be obtained by calling getSMSCount().

      • authenticate

        public void authenticate()
                  throws SMSException,
                         java.lang.Exception
        Authenticates a user for messaging.
        Throws:
        SMSException - Thrown if server request or authentication fails.
        java.lang.Exception - Throws for errors occurring before the request is sent to the server.
        Note:
        The account login and password must be set before calling this method. On successful authentication, some user and server settings are loaded that are required for sending messages. It is therefore recommended for authentication to be performed before setting message parameters. Failure to perform authentication before setting message parameters may throw Exception for some method calls.

      • extractPhoneNumbers

        public java.util.List<java.lang.String> extractPhoneNumbers(java.lang.String source)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Searches and extracts phone numbers from specified String input source.
        Parameters:
        source - The source from where phone numbers should be searched and extracted.
        Returns:
        Returns valid phone numbers found in the specified source.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown if source is null, empty, or when user authentication has not been performed for settings to be loaded.
        See Also:
        extractPhoneNumbers(java.lang.String, java.util.List)
        Note:
        The method searches through source and extracts valid phone numbers into a list of String object. The returned phone numbers are those that are valid for user routes. Therefore, a phone number may be valid and exist in source but if it is not allowed on user routes, it will not be included.

        source must be String object. For file sources, the contents of the file must loaded into a String object and specified as source for the method call.

      • extractPhoneNumbers

        public java.util.List<java.lang.String> extractPhoneNumbers(java.lang.String source,
                                                            java.util.List<java.lang.String> rejected)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Searches and extracts phone numbers from specified String input source.
        Parameters:
        source - The source from where phone numbers should be searched and extracted.
        rejected - Holds a list of rejected phone numbers either because they are invalid or not allowed on user routes.
        Returns:
        Returns valid phone numbers found in the specified source.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown if source is null or empty.
        See Also:
        extractPhoneNumbers(java.lang.String)
        Note:
        The method searches through source and extracts valid phone numbers into a list of String object. The returned phone numbers are those that are valid for user routes. Therefore, a phone number may be valid and exist in source but if it is not allowed on user routes, it will not be included.

        source must be String object. For file sources, the contents of the file must loaded into a String object and specified as source for the method call.

      • getMessageTypes

        public static java.util.List<java.lang.String> getMessageTypes()
                                                        throws java.lang.Exception
        Gets the String representations of all the MSGTYPE enumerations.
        Returns:
        Returns the String representation of all the MSGTYPE enumerations.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown if the message types have not been loaded from the SMS server.
        Note:
        The message types are loaded after a successful authentication. Therefore, it is important to perform authentication before calling this method for the message types.

        The String representations of the MSGTYPE enumeration can be shown to users for selection of the type of message to be submitted. Then when setting the message type, setMessageType(java.lang.String) can be called with the selected message type which will be converted to the corresponding MSGTYPE enumerator.

      • getTimeZones

        public static java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.util.List<java.lang.String[]>> getTimeZones()
                                                                                       throws java.lang.Exception
        Gets the time zones in the form of regions and cities. These are the values that are actually returned by PHP.
        Returns:
        Returns the time zone regions and cities as returned by PHP with underscores replaced by white spaces.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown if time zones have not been loaded. This will occur if authentication has not been performed.
        Note:
        The time zones are returned in a Map<String, List<String[]>> object. The regions such as Africa, Europe, Asia, America, etc., are contained in the keys while the cities for each region are contained in a List<String[]> object. Each item in the List is an array of String with the first index (0) being the city and the second index (1) being the time zone offset from GMT.

        The key and value pairs can be used, particularly in GUI forms, in the selection of a region and city in order to determine the time zone offset from GMT.

      • submit

        public java.util.List<java.lang.String[]> submit()
                                          throws SMSException,
                                                 java.lang.Exception
        Submits the composed message to the SMS server for submission to the added destinations.
        Returns:
        Returns either the submit responses for each destination or a token to be used for querying submit status.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown for errors occurring before the request is sent.
        SMSException - Thrown when server request fails.
        Note:
        The value returned from this method is dependent on the type of message submitted as well as the total number of destinations submitted.

        When sending non-personalised messages, the method returns either the submit status of the destinations or a token that can be used to query the submit status of the destinations. What is returned depends the total number of destinations submitted. If the total number of destinations submitted is less than the maximum submit value that is returned by getBatchSubmitMax(), the submit status of destinations will be returned in a List of String[] of length 2 with the submit status in the first index (0) and the destination in the second index (1), and message identifier in the with index 2.

      • getSubmitStatus

        public java.util.Map<STATUSQUERY,java.util.List<java.lang.String>> getSubmitStatus(java.lang.String token,
                                                                                   boolean loadests,
                                                                                   STATUSQUERY... states)
                                                                            throws SMSException,
                                                                                   java.lang.Exception
        Gets the status of submitted destinations from a query token.
        Parameters:
        token - A unique key that identifies the message which can be used to query the status of submitted destinations.
        loadests - Indicates whether the recipients of the message should be returned as well or not.
        states - The states of destinations that should be returned. Each must be separated with a comma.
        Returns:
        Returns the submit status of submitted destinations.
        Throws:
        SMSException - Thrown if the server request fails.
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown for errors occurring before the server request is sent.

      • getSubmitStatus

        public java.util.Map<STATUSQUERY,java.util.List<java.lang.String>> getSubmitStatus(java.lang.String token,
                                                                                   STATUSQUERY... states)
                                                                            throws SMSException,
                                                                                   java.lang.Exception
        Gets the status of submitted destinations from a query token.
        Parameters:

        states - The states of destinations that should be returned. Each must be separated with a comma.
        Returns:
        Returns the submit status of submitted destinations.
        Throws:
        SMSException - Thrown if the server request fails.
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown for errors occurring before the server request is sent.

      • getSenderId

        public java.lang.String getSenderId()
        Gets the identifier that will be shown to recipients as the sender of the message.
        Returns:
        Returns the identifier that will be shown to recipients as the sender of the message.
        Note:
        The method returns a default sender identifier if one has already been set for user account and setSenderId(java.lang.String) has not been called to overwrite it for the current session. If setSenderId(java.lang.String) has already been called, then the method returns the sender ID that was last set with setSenderId(java.lang.String). If no default sender ID has been set for user account and setSenderId(java.lang.String) has not been called to set one for the message, the return value will be empty.

        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown if url is null or invalid.

      • setMessage

        public void setMessage(java.lang.String msg)
                throws java.lang.Exception
        Sets the message that will be submitted to the recipients.
        Parameters:
        msg - The message to be submitted to the recipients.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown if msg is null or empty.
        Note:
        The method sets the message that will be delivered to mobile destinations added to the destinations list. There are certain issues that must be clearly understood when calling this method.

        When overwriting a previously set message, the method checks whether the set message contains variables for personalising message. If the previously set message has one or more variables defined in it, the method will clear the destinations list without notice before setting the new message. Again, if the new message to be set has variables defined in it, the destinations list will be cleared without notice and the new message will be set to replace the previous one.

        Thus, when overwriting a previously set message, the destinations list will be maintained only if both the new message and the previously set message do not have variables defined in them. Contrary to this, the added destinations will be cleared for the new message to replace the previously set one.

        Another important issue is that when sending personalised SMS, the message must be set before any phone numbers are added to the destinations list. For personalised messaging, if addRecipient(java.lang.String, java.lang.String[]) or addRecipient(java.lang.String, java.lang.String[], boolean) is called to add a destination before the message is set, Exception will be thrown.

      • getVariables

        public java.util.List<java.lang.String> getVariables()
                                              throws java.lang.Exception
        Gets a list of variables defined in the message for the calling object.
        Returns:
        Returns a list of variables defined in the message for the calling object.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown for errors occurring while processing request.
        See Also:
        getVariables(boolean)
        Note:
        If the message has not already been set or is empty, the return value will be null.

      • getVariables

        public java.util.List<java.lang.String> getVariables(boolean trim)
                                              throws java.lang.Exception
        Gets a list of variables defined in the message for the calling object.
        Parameters:
        trim - Indicates whether the variable definition characters should be removed from the name or not.
        Returns:
        Returns a list of variables defined in the message for the calling object.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown for error occurring when trimming variable names.
        See Also:
        getVariables()
        Note:
        If the message has not already been set or is empty, the return value will be null.

        When trim is true, the characters, {, $, }, which identify a variable will be removed from the variable names, otherwise they will be included in the names as defined in the message.

      • getVariables

        public static java.util.List<java.lang.String> getVariables(java.lang.String message,
                                                            boolean trim)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Gets a list of variables defined in a message for personalisation.
        Parameters:
        message - The source message from which to search and extract the variables defined in it.
        trim - Indicates whether only the actual names of the variables should be returned or not. That is, the names of the variables without the characters {, $, }, which identify a variable.
        Returns:
        Returns the list of variables found in message.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown for error occurring when trimming variable names.
        See Also:
        getVariables(java.lang.String)
        Note:
        When trim is set to true for this method call, only the name of the variable without the variable definition characters are returned.

      • getVariables

        public static java.util.List<java.lang.String> getVariables(java.lang.String message)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Gets a list of variables defined in a message for personalisation.
        Parameters:
        message - The source message from which to search and extract the variables defined in it.
        Returns:
        Returns the list of variables found in message.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown for error occurring while trimming variable names.
        See Also:
        getVariables(java.lang.String, boolean)
        Note:
        The method extracts the variables by trimming the names. That is, it takes away the characters {, $, }, which identify a variable.
